com.quest.glue.api.services
Interface CanonicalNameService

All Superinterfaces:
Service
public interface CanonicalNameService
extends Service

Service to provide canonical names for platforms and architectures. Many operating systems, architectures, and people refer to these using slightly different names. This service attempts to map those commonly used names to canonical values that can be consitently compared against each other using string comparisons.

Whenever such a name is required and expected to be used by rules and different parts of the Foglight product, the canonical name should be used.

Much more detailed information can be found for the local machine by using SystemInfoService3 to just ask for the values, rather then trying to find the strings and map them. This service is intended to be used when these values are coming from a remote system.

Method Summary
 java.lang.String getArchitecture(java.lang.String arch)
          Attempt to map a CPU architecture to its canonical type.
 java.lang.String getOperatingSystemType(java.lang.String name)
          Attempt to map an operating system name to its canonical type.
 

Method Detail

getArchitecture

java.lang.String getArchitecture(java.lang.String arch)
Attempt to map a CPU architecture to its canonical type. For example, there are a bunch of different ways used to identify 64-bit architectures. This will all be mapped to x86_64 for consisency.

If a mapping could not be found then FglAM will log a warning that there is a mapping missing before returning the original input string.

Parameters:
arch - The architecture to map
Returns:
The mapped architecture name or unknown if a mapping does not exist

getOperatingSystemType

java.lang.String getOperatingSystemType(java.lang.String name)
Attempt to map an operating system name to its canonical type. For example, "Windows NT", "Windows XP", "Windows Vista" will be mapped to "windows" so that they can all be identified as being the same.

If a mapping could not be found then FglAM will log a warning that there is a mapping missing before returning the input string.

Parameters:
name - The operating system name to map
Returns:
The mapped operating system type or unknown if a mapping does not exist
